text:
pilots of aircraft that are RTA capable are issued the TBFM-
derived STA as an RTA clearance by controllers. For aircraft that are not RTA capable, 
controllers use their DST capabilities (such as the speed advisories or DCT) to efficiently manage 
flights to meet the TBFM system generated STAs. When the required flight adjustment (i.e., iv crossing time delay) is predicted to exceed what can be accomplished at the current Flight Level 
with speed alone, the en route controller will need to either use a manual vector (e.g., s-turn) or 
issue an interim altitude clearance to a lower Flight Level and then revert to use of RTA when the 
automation determines it is feasible. Given that aircraft RTA equipage is not yet available as part 
of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) flight plan, several alternatives to 
determine RTA equipage by the operational system can be implemented. These alternatives 
include: using an aircraft equipage table to determine RTA capability or using an FAA specific 
extension of the ICAO flight plan to allow operators to submit RTA equipage information until a 
standardized ICAO version will be available.
Alternatively, if Path Stretch advisories are available (expected to be deployed within the same 
timeframe as TBM-RTA) the controllers will be able to assign the automation-provided path 
change solution along with an RTA to achieve the flight-specific crossing time. The Path Stretch 
advisory provides a two-legged maneuver (i.e., path change) for the flight that takes the aircraft 
off the current route to a specified point, expressed as a radial and nautical miles distance from an 
available adjacent navigation fix, and back toward the current route. If the controller decides to 
issue a Path Stretch advisory, the controller would communicate the path change to the pilot first 
followed by the RTA clearance; the pilot programs their FMS to input the path change and RTA 
command, in this order. Pilot confirmation to the controller that the RTA clearance is achievable 
is required; once that is confirmed, the controller would accept the advisory on the situation 
display which would update the MRP list for that flight.
If at any point during the RTA operation, it appears that the targeted flight-specific crossing time 
will not be met, the controller can suspend the TBM-RTA operation and revert to traditional 
strategies to meet the STA, such as applying speed control, vectoring, and altitude assignments. 
While the concept document describes how RTAs can be used in en route airspace both in the 
cruise phase of flight as well as in descent, for this evaluation the TBM-RTA concept was 
explored only during level flight in cruise in an extended metering (XM) context as depicted in 
Figure 2. v Figure 2. RTA with Path Stretch Advisories in Extended Metering Environment vi 1 Refers to simulations that provide instruction on only a part of the whole job or task. Part-Task Human in the Loop Simulation3
Following the development of the ConOps presented in Section 2, MITRE CAASD executed a 
part-task1 human-in-the-loop (HITL) evaluation to assess the operational feasibility of the 
concept [5]. Simulation Environment3.1
The simulation was conducted in the MITRE CAASD Aviation Integrated Demonstration and 
Experimentation for Aeronautics (IDEA) Lab. The hardware used for the simulation is the same 
hardware used by field controllers, including two 4K displays, keyboards, track ball, and push-to-
talk audio. Additionally, the evaluation occurred in a data collection environment that provided a 
similar general workstation layout and setup to that of sectors at an air traffic control facility. 
The software used to conduct the TBM-RTA Part Task Evaluation was a combination of actual 
(operational) software and an emulation of capabilities that are typically used as part of an Air 
Route Traffic Control Center (ARTCC) facility. The simulation software architecture was 
composed of the following distinct components: TBFM Applications: this consists of an operational version of the TBFM software 
that was integrated in the MITRE IDEA Lab. This version of TBFM software 
provides the ability to issue GIM-S Speed Advisories. TBFM Connector: MITRE software used to interface the IDEA Lab simulation assets 
to the operational TBFM system. The interfaces provide TBFM with track data and 
flight plans and also receives metering information from the TBFM system. En Route Automation Modernization (ERAM) Emulator: Consists of the MITRE 
Joint En Route Decision Support System (DSS) Infrastructure (JEDI) software that 
was built to provide an emulation of ERAM. The software includes prototyped Path 
Stretch functionality that has not yet been operationally developed or fielded. Controller Stations: This consists of the controller Display System Interface (DSI) 
emulation which is part of the ERAM software but is available as a modular 
component in the IDEA Lab. Flight Modeler: Consists of MITRE software capability used to realistically represent 
the characteristics of much of the current airplane fleet. Pseudo Pilots: Consists of an IDEA Lab software capability that can be used to 
control simulation traffic. The software is designed such that a single pilot can control 
multiple aircraft in a simulation. High-Fidelity FMS Flight Simulators3.2
In addition to aircraft simulated using the IDEA Lab flight model, aircraft simulators that utilize 
actual FMS control logic were also used in the simulation. The FMS simulators were introduced 
because they more closely represent behavior of commercial aircraft avionics, which was 
considered critical for evaluating the feasibility of TBM-RTA. In each of the four runs, two pilots 
flew two simulators. Figure 3 provides a snapshot of the FMS workstation interface used. As vii indicated, the software interface is complex because it incorporates a full FMS interface. 
Consequently, these simulators had to be staffed by dedicated Airline Transport Pilot License 
(ATPL) certified pilots, unlike the IDEA Lab simulated aircraft where one pseudo-pilot managed 
multiple aircraft at once. Figure 3. High Fidelity FMS Simulation Core TBM-RTA Software Functions3.3
Aside from the core software components described in Section 3.1, additional software 
modifications were implemented on the ATC automation to support the TBM-RTA concept 
evaluation. A summary of the core software functions implemented is described here. 
One core function consists of the RTA assignment and tracking functions, which provides 
controllers the means to monitor RTA assignments as aircraft progress through the sector and are 
handed off to subsequent sectors. Figure 4 shows an example for an aircraft that has been issued 
an RTA clearance. As indicated, the MRP List is updated with the RTA assignment. 
Additionally, the data block is updated to indicate the assigned RTA. viii Figure 4. RTA Assignment and Tracking Another software change was made to clearly show to the controller which flights are and are not 
RTA-equipped. The STA on the MRP list is bold and underlined for flights that are RTA 
equipped, as shown by SWA474 in Figure 5. Non-equipped flights have gray STAs, such as 
AAL433. Once a flight is assigned an RTA or speed clearance, the RTA or speed is listed in the 
Speed (SPD) column (the right-most column). This is a critical feature as not all aircraft will be 
capable of performing an RTA. Figure 5. RTA-equipped Flights on MRP List Operational Scenario3.4
The concept was evaluated in a two-sector, en route environment representing the northeast 
cornerpost flow into Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport (KPHX) in the Albuquerque 
ARTCC, abbreviated ZAB. The two sectors simulated were ZAB 93, which primarily handles 
flights in their cruise phase, and ZAB 39, which handles the descent phase of the arrival prior to 
entering the TRACON. The focus of the evaluation was the metering operations in ZAB 93 
(highlighted in dark blue) to the extended metering point (XMP) identified as SLIDR 
(pronounced slider). SLIDR is located at the en route merge near the airspace sector boundary 
of ZAB 93 and ZAB 39 on the EAGUL6 Arrival Procedure (solid black line), as depicted in 
Figure 6. ix Figure 6. ZAB Airspace Simulated During the HITL SLIDR is also a coupled meter point (CMP) in relation to the meter fix (MF), identified as 
HOMRR (pronounced homer). That means the sequence of flights crossing SLIDR is held 
constant (or coupled) with the sequence of those same flights across HOMRR. In the current 
operation, HOMRR is where the en route traffic is delivered to the TRACON. 
In this evaluation, all operations were executed with voice communication. Controllers were 
asked to issue (based on equipage) RTA clearances or advisory-provided speed clearances to 
SLIDR to make the flight adjustments necessary to meet the targeted crossing times in the 
extended metering environment. Path Stretch advisories were also provided by automation to be 
used in combination either with the RTA or speed clearance in cases where the flight adjustment 
needed could not be accomplished with speed or time alone. Controllers were notified if a Path 
Stretch was necessary once a flight crosses the FH for SLIDR (Figure 6). Controller participants 
were also instructed to meet MRP crossing times as accurately as possible while ensuring 
separation. Flights were expected to cross SLIDR within 30 seconds of the STA. Evaluation Phraseology 3.5
In this evaluation, all operations were executed with voice communications. Controllers issued 
speeds, RTAs, path changes, or a combination of those clearances to meet the TBFM system 
generated
